citation.article-title: Saccharopolyspora spinosporotrichia sp. nov., a novel actinomycete from soil.

p.s: Description of Saccharopolyspora spinosporotrichia sp. nov.
Saccharopolyspora spinosporotrichia (spi.no.spo.ro. tri. chi.a. L. adj. spinosus thorny; M.L. n. spora a spore; M.L. n. trichia trichite; spinosporotrichia spores bearing needle-like spines)

Aerobic, Gram-positive, non-acid-alcohol-fast actinomycete which forms an extensively branched, reddish-brown substrate mycelium which fragments into rod-shaped elements; abundant white to grey aerial hyphae are produced.
Long spiral spore chains are borne on the aerial mycelium.
The spores are spherical with warty surfaces.
Good growth occurs on Bennett's, Czapek, Gause's synthetic, inorganic salts-starch, oatmeal and sucrose yeast extract agars.
Aerial mycelium production is poor on yeast-maltose extract agar.
A brown diffusible pigment is formed on many standard media.
Casein and gelatin are degraded but not cellulose, starch or tyrosine.
H2S is not produced nor is nitrate reduced.

The organism can use D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, glycerol, meso-inositol, D-maltose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, D-melibiose, D-ribose, D-sorbitol, D-sucrose and D-xylose as sole carbon sources for energy and growth, but not L-arabinose, D-lactose and D-sorbose.
Grows between 25 and 37Â°C and in the presence of 2-3 % (w/v) sodium chloride.
The G + C content of the DNA is 70.4 mol%.
The remaining chemical properties of the strain were given earlier.
The organism was isolated from soil.
The type strain is Saccharopolyspora spinosporotrichia AS4.198 (Chinese Culture Collection of Microorganisms).
